title: 110_hr5962
content: The "Keep Our Homes Act of 2008" includes a temporary deduction for certain mortgage counseling under section 224 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The "Keep Our Homes Act of 2008" allows a deduction for qualified mortgage counseling expenses up to $500 per year. Qualified counseling must be obtained from an organization accredited by the Federal Housing Administration before obtaining a loan secured by the taxpayer's principal residence. The deduction is not allowed for expenses incurred after December 31, 2012. The deduction for mortgage counseling expenses up to $500 per year is allowed until December 31, 2012. Section 62 of the tax code is amended to include this deduction. The deduction for mortgage counseling expenses up to $500 per year is allowed until December 31, 2012. Section 224 introduces certain mortgage counseling provisions, effective for taxable years starting after December 31, 2007. Additionally, a temporary deduction for upside-down mortgages is introduced under section 225 of the Internal Revenue Code. The deduction allowed for mortgage counseling expenses is up to $500 per year until December 31, 2012. It also introduces provisions for upside-down mortgages under the Internal Revenue Code. The deduction for acquisition indebtedness on the taxpayer's principal residence is limited to 20% of the excess over the valuation for real property tax assessments, not exceeding $5,000 per year. Acquisition indebtedness obtained fraudulently will not be considered for this deduction, and it is not allowed for amounts paid or incurred after December 31, 2009. The deduction for mortgage counseling expenses is limited to $500 per year until December 31, 2012. A new provision for upside-down mortgages is added to the Internal Revenue Code, allowing a deduction under section 224. The deduction is not allowed for amounts paid or incurred after December 31, 2009. The amendment allows for a deduction for upside-down mortgages under section 225, effective for taxable years starting after December 31, 2007. Additionally, a temporary credit for certain home purchases is introduced under section 25E of the Internal Revenue Code. The amendment introduces a temporary credit for home purchases, allowing individuals to claim a credit against the tax imposed by the chapter for a qualified principal residence purchase. The credit is equal to 10% of the purchase price or $7,500 ($9,000 in high-cost areas) and is divided equally over two taxable years. Limitations include purchases made after the enactment date but before 12 months after. The temporary credit for home purchases allows individuals to claim a credit for a qualified principal residence purchase. The credit is 10% of the purchase price or $7,500 ($9,000 in high-cost areas) divided over two taxable years. Limitations apply to purchases made after the enactment date but before 12 months after. The tax credit for home purchases is limited based on the taxpayer's modified adjusted gross income. The credit allowed for any taxable year cannot exceed the sum of the regular tax liability plus the tax imposed by section 55, minus the credits allowable under this subpart for the taxable year. This limitation applies to taxable years where section 26(a)(2) does not apply. The tax credit for home purchases is limited based on the taxpayer's modified adjusted gross income. If a credit is allowed for the purchase of a qualified principal residence, no credit shall be allowed for the purchase of any other qualified principal residence in the same taxable year. Additionally, if a qualified principal residence is purchased jointly, no credit shall be allowed if any individual has already claimed the credit in a previous taxable year. No credit is allowed under this section if it has been claimed for the purchase of another qualified principal residence in the same taxable year or if a credit has been claimed in a previous year by any individual involved in a joint purchase. The term 'qualified principal residence' refers to a residence purchased to be the purchaser's main residence, with no double benefit allowed for purchases eligible for credit under another section. If the qualified principal residence is disposed of or not occupied as the principal residence, recapture of the credit may be required. If a taxpayer disposes of or fails to occupy their qualified principal residence within 24 months of purchase, the remaining portion of the credit allowed will be disallowed. Special rules apply for joint purchases, with adjustments for married individuals filing separately and unmarried individuals. The tax credit for purchasing a qualified principal residence can be allocated among unmarried individuals, not exceeding $7,000 in total. Rules similar to those for purchase and reporting requirements apply, and the basis of the residence is adjusted if the credit is allowed. The basis of a residence is reduced by the amount of the credit allowed under this section. Conforming amendments are made to various sections of the Internal Revenue Code to include the new credit provision. Section 904(i) of the Internal Revenue Code is amended to include section 25E. Section 1016(a) is also amended to reference section 25E(g). Additionally, section 1400C(d)(2) is amended to include section 25E. A clerical amendment is made to the table of sections to include section 25E after section 25D. Section 25E provides a credit for certain home purchases, with amendments applying to purchases in taxable years after the enactment of the Act. The amendment is subject to the Economic Growth and Tax Relief Reconciliation Act of 2001. Additionally, there is a temporary additional standard deduction for real property taxes for nonitemizers. In 2008 or 2009, a new real property tax deduction is added to the Internal Revenue Code, allowing taxpayers to deduct eligible state and local real property taxes up to $500 ($1,000 for joint returns). The new real property tax deduction added in 2008 or 2009 allows taxpayers to deduct eligible state and local real property taxes, with a limit of $500 ($1,000 for joint returns). The deduction applies to taxable years starting after December 31, 2007. SEC. 6. TEMPORARY EXCLUSION OF UNEMPLOYMENT COMPENSATION FROM GROSS INCOME. Amends the Internal Revenue Code to exclude unemployment compensation from gross income for individuals in 2008 or 2009. Effective for amounts received after December 31, 2007.
